distribution.name: arcsine distribution
Levy arcsine distribution
distribution.model: The arcsine distribution models the proportion of time that Brownian motion is positive
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{2}{\pi}\arcsin\left(\sqrt \frac{x - a}{w}\right)\)
distribution.qf: \(Q(u) = a + w \sin^2\left(\frac{\pi}{2} u\right), \; u \in (0, 1)\)
distribution.mgf: \( M(t) = e^{a t} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \left(\prod_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{2 j + 1}{2 j + 2}\right) \frac{w^n t^n}{n!}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty) \)
distribution.history: Derived by Paul Levy in 1939 as the distribution of proportion of time that Brownian motion is positive

distribution.name: Bernoulli distribution
distribution.model: The Bernoulli distribution governs an indicator random variable
distribution.qf: \(Q(u) = F^{-1}(u), \; u \in [0, 1]\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: Named for Jacob Bernoulli

distribution.name: beta distribution
distribution.model: The beta distribution is used to model random proportions and probabilities
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \frac{1}{B(\alpha, \beta)} x^{\alpha-1}(1 - x)^{\beta-1}, \; x \in (0, 1)\), where \( B \) is the beta function
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{B(x; \alpha, \beta)}{B(\alpha, \beta)}, \; x \in (0, 1)\), where \( x \mapsto B(x; \alpha, \beta) \) is the incomplete beta function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\), where \(F\) is the beta cumulative distribution function.

distribution.name: beta general distribution
beta generalized distribution
generalized beta distribution
distribution.model: The generalized beta distribution is used to model random proportions and probabilities. It extends the (standard) beta distribution, supported on \([0, 1]\) to an arbitrary range \([L, R]\)
distribution.parameter: \(L \in (-\infty, \infty)\), the left limit of the support range
\(R \in (L, \infty)\), the right limit of the support range
distribution.pdf: \(\begin{cases} \frac{\beta}{R - L} & \text{for } x < L \text{ or } X > R \\ \frac{\beta}{R - L} & \text{for } x == L \text{ and } \alpha == 1 \\ \infty & \text{for } x == L \text{ and } \alpha > 1 \\ 0 & \text{for } x == L \text{ and } \alpha > 1 \\ \frac{\alpha}{R - L} & \text{for } x == R \text{ and } \beta == 1 \\ \infty & \text{for } x == R \text{ and } \beta < 1 \\ 0 & \text{for } x == R \text{ and } \beta > 1 \\ \exp(\log\Gamma(\alpha + \beta) - (\log\Gamma(\alpha) + \log\Gamma(\beta)) - \log(R - L) + (\alpha-1)*\log(\frac{x-L}{R-L})+(\beta-1)*\log(\frac{R-x}{R-L})) & otherwise \end{cases}\)
distribution.mode: \(\begin{cases} L & \text{for } \alpha <1 \\ R & \text{for } \beta \leq 1 \\ L + \frac{(R - L) * (\alpha - 1)}{a + b - 2} & otherwise \end{cases}\)
distribution.cdf: \(I_{\frac{x-L}{R}}(\alpha,\beta)\!\)

distribution.name: inverse beta distribution
distribution.model: The inverse beta distribution, as the name suggests, is the inverse probability dsitribution of a Beta-distributed variable
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = B(\frac{x}{1+x}; \alpha,\beta) \), where \(B(x; \alpha,\beta)\) is the incomplete beta function

distribution.name: binomial distribution
distribution.model: The binomial distribution models the number of successes in a fixed number of independent trials each with the same probability of success
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = {n \choose x} p^x (1 - p)^{n - x}, \; x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = B(1 - p; n - x, x + 1), \; x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\) where \(B\) is the incomplete beta function
distribution.qf: \(Q(r) = F^{-1}(r), \; r \in [0, 1]\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The binomial distribution is attributed to Jacob Bernoulli

distribution.name: beta-binomial distribution
distribution.model: The beta-binomial distribution arises when the success parameter in the binomial distribution is randomized and given a beta distribution
distribution.pdf: \( f(x) = \binom{n}{x} \frac{a^{[x]} b^{[n - x]}}{(a + b)^{[n]}} \), \( x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\} \) where \( m^{[j]} \) denotes the rising power of \( m \) of order \( j \)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_0^x f(t), \quad x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \quad p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.skew: \(\frac{(a + b + 2 n)(b - a)}{(a + b + 2)} \sqrt{\frac{1 + a + b}{n a b (n + a + b)}}\)

distribution.name: beta-negative binomial distribution
distribution.model: The beta-negative binomial distribution arises when the success parameter in the negative binomial distribution is randomized and given a beta distribution
distribution.pdf: \( f(x) = \binom{n - 1}{x - 1} \frac{a^{[x]} b^{[n-x]}}{(a + b)^{[n]}} \), where \( r^{[j]} \) denotes the rising power of order \( j \)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_0^x f(t), \quad x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \quad p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function

distribution.name: Cauchy distribution
Cauchy-Lorentz distribution
Lorentz distribution
Breit-Wigner distribution
distribution.model: The general Cauchy distribution is the location-scale family associated with the standard Cauchy distribution
distribution.cdf: \(\frac{1}{\pi}\arctan\left(\frac{x - a}{b} \right) + \frac{1}{2} \)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p) = a + b \tan \left(\pi (p - \frac{1}{2}) \right), \; p \in (0, 1)\)
distribution.history: The distribution was first used by Simeon Poisson in 1824 and was re-introduced by Augustin Cauchy in 1853. It is also named for Hendrick Lorentz

distribution.name: chi-square distribution
chi-squared distribution
distribution.model: The chi-square distribution governs the sum of squares of independent standard normal variable
distribution.pdf: \(\frac{1}{2^{\frac{n}{2}}\Gamma\left(\frac{n}{2}\right)}\; x^{\frac{n}{2}-1} e^{-\frac{x}{2}}\,\), where \(\Gamma\) is the Gamma function
distribution.cdf: \(\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(\frac{n}{2}\right)}\;\gamma\left(\frac{n}{2},\,\frac{x}{2}\right)\), where \(\gamma\) is the lower incomplete Gamma function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in [0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.entropy: \(\frac{n}{2} + \ln[2 \Gamma(n / 2)] + (1 - n / 2) \psi(n / 2)\), where \(\psi\) is the Digamma function
distribution.history: The chi-square distribution was first used by Karl Pearson in 1900

distribution.name: non-central chi-square distribution
non-central chi-squared distribution
distribution.model: The non-central chi-square distribution distribution is a generalization of the chi-squared distribution, which arises in the power analysis of statistical tests where the null distribution is asymptotically a chi-squared distribution; important examples of such tests are the likelihood ratio tests
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 1 - Q_{\frac{k}{2}} \left( \sqrt{\lambda}, \sqrt{x} \right)\), where \(Q_M(a,b)\) is the Marcum Q-function

distribution.name: chi distribution
distribution.model: The chi distribution governs the square root of a variable with the chi-square distribution
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.moments: \(\mu(k) = \frac{2^{k/2} \Gamma[(n+k)/2)]}{\Gamma(n/2)}, \; n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function

distribution.name: continuous uniform distribution
rectangular distribution
distribution.model: The continuous uniform distribution governs a point chosen at random from an interval. The continuous uniform distribution, aka rectangular distribution, is a family of probability distributions where all intervals of the same length on the distribution's support are equally probable. The support is defined by the two parameters, a and b, which are its minimum and maximum values. It is the maximum entropy probability distribution for a random variate X under no constraint other than that it is contained in the distribution's support
distribution.parameter: \( w \in (0, \infty) \), scale, the width of the interval
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{x - a}{b - a}, \; x \in [a, b]\)
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = \frac{e^{i t b} - e^{i t a}}{i t (b - a)}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\)

distribution.name: discrete uniform distribution
distribution.model: The discrete uniform distribution governs a point chosen at random from a discrete interval
distribution.pdf: \( f(x) = \frac{1}{n}, \; x \in \{a, a + h, \ldots, a + (n - 1) h\}\)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{1}{n}\left(\left \lfloor\ \frac{x - a}{h} + 1\right \rfloor \right), \; x \in [a, b] \)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = a + \left(\lceil n p \rceil - 1\right) h, \; p \in (0, 1] \)
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = \frac{1}{n} e^{t a} \frac{1 - e^{n t h}}{1 - e^{t h}}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\)
distribution.median: \(Q\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \) where \( Q \) is the quantile function
distribution.q1: \(Q\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\) where \( Q \) is the quantile function
distribution.q3: \(Q\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\) where \( Q \) is the quantile function

distribution.name: exponential distribution
negative exponential distribution
distribution.model: The exponential distribution models the time between random points in the Poisson model
distribution.history: The exponential distribution was named by Karl Pearson in 1895

distribution.name: exponential-logarithmic distribution
distribution.model: The exponential-logarithmic distribution models failure times of devices with decreasing failure rate
distribution.qf: \(Q(u) = b \ln\left(\frac{1 - p}{1 - p^{1 - u}}\right), \; u \in (0, 1)\)
distribution.moments: \(\mu(n) = -n! b^n \frac{L_{n+1}(1 - p)}{\ln(p)}, \; n \in \{0, 1, \ldots\}\) where \(L_{n+1}\) is the polylog function of order \(n + 1\)
distribution.mean: \(-b \frac{L_2(1 - p)}{\ln(p)}\) where \(L_2\) is the polylog function of order \(2\).
distribution.variance: \(-b^2 \frac{2 L_3(1 - p)}{ln(p)} - \frac{L_2^2(1 - p)}{b^2 \ln^2(p)}\) where \(L_n\) is the polylog function of order \(n\)

distribution.name: exponential power distribution
generalized error distribution
distribution.model: The exponential power distribution is a family of symmetric, unimodal distributions that generalizes the normal and Laplace families
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \frac{\beta}{2 \alpha \Gamma(1/\beta)} \exp\left[-\left(\frac{|x - \mu|}{\alpha}\right)^\beta\right], \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sgn(x - \mu)}{2 \Gamma (1 / \beta)} \gamma\left[\frac{1}{\beta}, \left(\frac{|x - \mu|}{\alpha}\right)^\beta\right], \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\), where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function and \(\gamma\) is the lower incomplete gamma function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \quad p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function

distribution.name: F-distribution
Snedecor's F-distribution
Fisher-Snedecor distribution
distribution.model: The F-distribution governs the ratio of independent, scaled chi-square variables
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{B[n x / (n x + d), n/2, d/2]}{B(n/2, d/2)}, \; x \in [0, \infty)\), where \( B \) is the beta function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The \(F\)-distribution was first derived by George Snedecor in 1934. The letter F was chosen as a tribute to Ronald Fisher

distribution.name: gamma distribution
distribution.model: The gamma distribution governs the arrival times in the Poisson model, and has many applications in statistics
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \frac{1}{\Gamma(k) b^k} x^{k - 1}e^{-x / b}, \; x \in (0, \infty) \) where \( \Gamma \) is the gamma function
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \frac{1}{\Gamma(k)} \gamma\left(k, \frac{x}{b}\right) \) where \( \gamma \) is the incomplete gamma function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function

distribution.name: geometric distribution
distribution.model: The geometric distribution models the trial number of the first success in a sequence of Bernoulli trials
distribution.qf: \(Q(u) = \left\lceil \frac{\ln(1 - u)}{\ln(1 - p)} \right\rceil, \; u \in [0, 1)\)
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = \frac{p e^{i t}}{1 - (1 - p) e^{i t}}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\)
distribution.history: The geometric distribution was used very early in the history of probability, but the name has been attributed to William Feller in 1950

distribution.name: hypergeometric distribution
distribution.model: The hypergeometric distribution governs the number of objects of a given type when sampling without replacement from a multi-type population
distribution.parameter: \(m\), the number of type 1 objects in the population
distribution.pdf: \( f(x) = \frac{\binom{m}{x} \binom{N - m}{n - x}}{\binom{N}{n}}, \; x \in \left\{\max{(0,\, n+m-N)},\, \dots,\, \min{(m,\, n )}\right\} \)
distribution.cdf: \(1-{{{n \choose {k+1}}{{N-n} \choose {m-k-1}}}\over {N \choose m}} \,_3F_2\!\!\left[\begin{array}{c}1,\ k+1-m,\ k+1-n \\ k+2,\ N+k+2-m-n\end{array};1\right]\), where \(_pF_q(a,b;c;z)\) is the generalized hypergeometric function.
distribution.mgf: \(\frac{{N-m \choose n} \scriptstyle{\,_2F_1(-n, -m; N - m - n + 1; e^{t}) } } {{N \choose n}} \,\!\)
distribution.kurt: \(\left[ \frac{N^2 (N-1)}{n(N - 2)(N - 3)(N - n)}\right] \left[ \frac{N(N+1) - 6 N(N - n)}{m (N - m)} + \frac{3 n (N - n)(N + 6)}{N^2} - 6 \right]\)
distribution.history: The hypergeometric distribution is very old, and was used by Jacob Bernoulli, Abraham DeMoivre, and others. The named was coined by H.T. Gonin in 1936

distribution.name: hyperbolic secant distribution
distribution.model: The hyperbolic secant distribution is a symmetric, unimodal distribution but with larger kurtosis than the normal distribution
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \frac{2}{\pi} \arctan\left\{\exp\left[\frac{\pi}{2} \left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \right) \right]\right\}, \; x \in (-\infty, \infty) \)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = \mu + \sigma \frac{2}{\pi} \ln[\tan(\frac{\pi}{2} p)], \; p \in (0, 1)\)

distribution.name: Irwin-Hall distribution
distribution.model: The Irwin-Hall distribution governs the sum of \(n\) independent variables, each uniformly distributed on \([0, 1]\)
distribution.history: The Irwin-Hall distribution is named for Joseph Irwin and Phillip Hall who independently analyzed the distribution in 1927

distribution.name: inverted beta distribution
beta prime distribution
beta distribution of the second kind
distribution.model: The inverted beta distribution is conjugate for the odds in the Bernoulli distribution
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \int_0^x f(t) dt, \; x \in (0, \infty)\), where \(f\) is the probability density function. Alternatively, \(F(x)=B(\frac{x}{1+x}; \alpha,\beta) \), where \( B(x; \alpha,\beta)\) is the incomplete beta function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function

distribution.name: Laplace distribution
double exponential distribution
distribution.model: The Laplace distribution is a symmetric, unimodal distribution with tails that are fatter than those of the normal distribution
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{2} \exp\left(\frac{x - a}{b}\right), & x \in (-\infty, a] \\ 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp\left(-\frac{x - a}{b}\right), & x \in [a, \infty) \end{cases} \)
distribution.history: The Laplace distribution is named for Pierre Simon Laplace

distribution.name: Levy distribution
van der Waals profile
stable distribution
distribution.model: The Levy distribution is a stable distribution that has applications in spectroscopy
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = 2 \left[1 - \Phi\left(\sqrt{\frac{b}{x - a}}\right)\right], \; x \in (a, \infty) \) where \( \Phi \) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.qf: \( F^{-1}(p) = a + \frac{b}{\left[\Phi^{-1}(1 - p / 2)\right]^2}, \; p \in [0, 1) \) where \( \Phi^{-1} \) is the standard normal quantile function
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = \exp\left(i a t - \sqrt{-2 i b t}\right), \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\)
distribution.median: \( a + b \left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\right]^{-2}\) where \(\Phi^{-1}\) is the standard normal quantile function
distribution.q1: \( a + b \left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{7}{8}\right)\right]^{-2}\) where \(\Phi^{-1}\) is the standard normal quantile function
distribution.q3: \( a + b \left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{5}{8}\right)\right]^{-2}\) where \(\Phi^{-1}\) is the standard normal quantile function
distribution.history: The Levy distribution is named for Paul Pierre Levy

distribution.name: Landau distribution
distribution.model: The Landau distribution is used in physics to describe the fluctuations in the energy loss of a charged particle passing through a thin layer of matter. This distribution is a special case of the stable Levy distribution with parameters (1, 1)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \int_1^x f(t) dt, \; x \in \) where \(f\) is the probability density function

distribution.name: logarithmic distribution
logarithmic series distribution
log-series distribution
distribution.model: The logarithmic distribution is sometimes used to model relative species abundance
distribution.cdf: \(F(k) = 1 + \frac{B(p; k + 1, 0)}{\ln(1 - p)}, \; k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\} \) where \( B \) is the incomplete beta function
distribution.history: The logarithmic distribution was first derived by Ronald Fisher in 1943

distribution.name: logistic distribution
distribution.model: The logistic distribution occurs in logistic regression
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(x - a)/b}}, \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = a + b \ln\left(\frac{p}{1 - p}\right), \; p \in (0, 1)\)
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = e^{a t} B(1 - b t, 1 + b t)\) where \(B\) is the beta function
distribution.history: Logistic regression was first used by D.R. Cox in 1958

distribution.name: generalized logistic distribution
skew logistic distribution
distribution.model: The generalized logistic distribution represents several different families of probability distributions. One family is called the skew-logistic distribution. Other families of distributions that have also been called generalized ogistic distributions include the shifted log-logistic distribution, which is a generalization of the log-logistic distribution
distribution.pdf: \(f(x;\alpha,\beta)=\frac{1}{B(\alpha,\beta)}\frac{\exp(-\beta x)} {(1+\exp(-x))^{\alpha+\beta}}\), where \(B\) is the beta function.

distribution.name: log-normal distribution
log normal distribution
lognormal distribution
Galton distribution
distribution.model: The log-normal distribution models certain skewed variables
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \Phi\left[\frac{\ln(x) - \mu}{\sigma}\right], \; x \in (0, \infty)\) where \( \Phi \) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.qf: \(F^{-1}(p) = \exp\left[\mu + \sigma \Phi^{-1}(p)\right]\), where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.q1: \(\exp\left[\mu + \sigma \Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\right]\), where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.q3: \(\exp\left[\mu + \sigma \Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\right]\), where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.history: The lognormal distribution was first studied by Donald McAlister in 1879, in response to a problem posed by Francis Galton. This historical origin is the reason for the alternative name Galton distribution. The term lognormal distribution was first used by J.H. Gaddum in 1945

distribution.name: log-logistic distribution
Fisk distribution
distribution.model: The log-logistic distribution models lifetimes of devices whose failure rates at first increase and then decrease
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{x^k}{b^k + x^k}, \; x \in [0, \infty)\)
distribution.moments: \(\mu(n) = b^n \frac{\pi n / k}{\sin(\pi n / k)}, \; n \lt k\)
distribution.mean: \( \infty \) if \( 0 \lt k \le 1 \); \(b \frac{\pi / k}{\sin(\pi / k)}\) if \( k \gt 1 \)
distribution.variance: does not exist if \( 0 \lt k \le 1 \); \( \infty \) if \( 1 \lt k \le 2 \); \( b^2 \left[\frac{2 \pi / k}{\sin(2 \pi / k)} - \frac{\pi^2 / k^2}{\sin^2(\pi / k)}\right] \) if \( k \gt 2 \)
distribution.history: The log-logistic distribution is known as the Fisk distribution by economists. P.R. Fisk used the distribution to model income in 1961

distribution.name: Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution
Maxwell distribution
distribution.model: The Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution arises in the kinetic theory of gases
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 2 \Phi\left(\frac{x}{b}\right) - \frac{1}{b} \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} x \exp\left(-\frac{x^2}{2 b^2}\right) - 1\) where \( \Phi \) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The Maxwell-Boltzman distribution is named for James Clerk Maxwell and Ludwig Boltzmann for their use of the distribution is modeling the energy of molecules in a gas

distribution.name: negative binomial distribution
Pascal distribution
distribution.model: The negative binomial distribution governs the number of trials (x) needed for a specified number of successes (k) in the Bernoulli trials model
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j=k}^x f(j) , \; x \in \{k, k+1, \ldots\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function. It can also be expressed as \(1-I_p(x-r+1,\,k) \), where \(I_p\) is the regularized incomplete beta function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The alternative name Pascal distribution is in honor of Blaise Pascal who used the distribution in his solution to the Problem of Points

distribution.name: normal distribution
Gaussian distribution
error distribution
distribution.model: The normal distribution is used to model physical quantities that are subject to numerous small, random errors
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \Phi\left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\right), \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.history: The normal distribution was first derived by Carl Friedrich Gauss in 1809 (hence the alternative name Gaussian distribution). The normalizing constant and the first version of the Central Limit Theorem were contributions by Pierre Simon Laplace. The term normalizing constant was popularized by Karl Pearson around the turn of the 20th century

distribution.name: students t distribution
Student's t distribution
t distribution
distribution.model: The t distribution arises when estimating the mean of a normally distributed population when the sample size is small and population standard deviation is unknown. It comes into play in various statistical analyses like Students t-test for assessing the between-group statistical significant differences of two sample means, construction of confidence intervals for difference between two population means, linear regression analyses, etc. Like the normal distribution, the t-distribution is symmetric, bell-shaped and unimodal. However it has heavier tails, meaning that it is more prone to producing values that fall far from its mean. The Students t-distribution is a special case of the generalized hyperbolic distribution
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{n + 1}{2} \right)} {\sqrt{n \pi} \Gamma \left(\frac{n}{2} \right)} \left(1 + \frac{x^2}{n} \right)^{-\frac{n + 1}{2}}, \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \( \Gamma \) is the gamma function
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{1}{2} + x \Gamma \left( \frac{n + 1}{2} \right) \frac{\,_2F_1 \left ( \frac{1}{2},\frac{n + 1}{2};\frac{3}{2}; - \frac{x^2}{n} \right)} {\sqrt{\pi n}\,\Gamma \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)}, \; x \in (-\infty, \infty)\), where \({ }_2F_1\) is the hypergeometric function
distribution.entropy: \(\frac{n + 1}{2}\left[\psi \left(\frac{1 + n}{2} \right) - \psi \left(\frac{n}{2} \right) \right] + \log{\left[\sqrt{n} B \left(\frac{n}{2}, \frac{1}{2} \right)\right]} \), where \(\psi\) is the digamma function and \(B\) is the beta function

distribution.name: truncated normal distribution
distribution.model: The truncated normal distribution is the probability distribution of a normally distributed random variable (\(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2) \)) whose value is either bounded below, above or on both sides. The truncated normal distribution has wide applications in statistics and econometrics
distribution.cdf: \(F(x;\mu,\sigma,a,b)=\frac{\Phi(\xi)-\Phi(\alpha)}{Z}\), where \( \phi(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp{(-\frac{1}{2}\xi^2)} \) is the probability density function of the standard normal distribution, \( \Phi(\cdot) \) is the standard normal cumulative distribution function, \( Z=\Phi(\beta)-\Phi(\alpha) \), \( \xi=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\), \(\alpha=\frac{a-\mu}{\sigma}\), \(\beta=\frac{b-\mu}{\sigma}\).

distribution.name: Pareto distribution
Bradford distribution
distribution.model: The Pareto distribution models highly skewed variables that sometimes arise in economics
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 1 - \left(\frac{b}{x}\right)^a, \; x \in [b, \infty)\)
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = a (-i b t)^a \gamma(-a, -i b t)\) where \(\gamma\) is the lower incomplete gamma function
distribution.history: The Pareto distributin is named for the Italian economist Vilfredo Pareto, who used the distribution to model wealth, income and other economic variables.

distribution.name: Poisson distribution
distribution.model: The Poisson distribution models the number of random points in a region of time or space under certain ideal conditions
distribution.mode: \(\lfloor\lambda\rfloor\) if \( \lambda \) is not an integer; \( \lambda \) and \( \lambda - 1 \) if \( \lambda \) is a positive integer
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \frac{1}{x!} \gamma(x + 1, \lambda), \; x \in \{0, 1, 2, \ldots\}\) where \(\gamma\) is the lower incomplete gamma function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The Poisson distribution is named for Simeon Poisson who first used the distribution in 1838 in a study of judgements in court cases

distribution.name: Rademacher distribution
distribution.model: The Rademacher distribution arises in physics and in bootstrapping
distribution.cdf: \(F(k)=\begin{cases}0,&k<-1\\1/2,&-1\leq k<1\\1,&k\geq1\end{cases}\)
distribution.history: The Rademacher distribution is named for the German mathematician Hans Rademacher

distribution.name: Rayleigh distribution
distribution.model: The Rayleigh distribution governs the magnitude of a vector with independent, normal components that have zero mean and the same variance
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 1 - \exp\left(-\frac{x^2}{2 \sigma^2}\right), \; x \in [0, \infty)\)
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = 1 + \sqrt{2 \pi} \sigma t \exp\left(\frac{\sigma^2 t^2}{2}\right) \Phi(t), \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.moments: \(\mu(n) = \sigma^n 2^{n/2} \Gamma\left(1 + \frac{n}{2}\right), \; n \in [0, \infty)\), where \(\Gamma\) denotes the gamma function
distribution.history: The Rayleigh distribution is named for the English mathematician Lord Rayleigh (John William Strutt)

distribution.name: Rice distribution
Rician distribution
distribution.model: The Rice distribution governs the magnitude of a circular bivariate normal random vector
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 1 - Q\left(\frac{\nu}{\sigma}, \frac{x}{\sigma}\right), \; x \in [0, \infty)\) where \(Q\) is the Marcum \(Q\)-function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The Rice distribution is named for Stephen O. Rice who used the distribution in 1945 in his study of random noise

distribution.name: semicircle distribution
Wigner distribution
Stato-Tate distribution
distribution.model: The semicircle distribution arises as the limiting distribution of the eigenvalues of random symmetric matrices
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{x - a}{\pi r^2} \sqrt{r^2 - (x - a)^2} + \frac{1}{\pi} \arcsin\left(\frac{x - a}{r}\right), \; x \in [a - r, a + r] \)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in [0, 1]\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = 2 e^{t a} \frac{I_1(r t)}{r t}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \(I_1\) is the modified Bessel function
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = 2 e^{i t a} \frac{J_1(r t)}{r t}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\) where \(J_1\) is the Bessel function
distribution.moments: For \( a = 0 \), \( \mu(2 n) = \left(\frac{r}{2}\right)^{2 n} \frac{1}{n + 1} \binom{2n}{n} \) and \( \mu(2 n + 1) = 0 \) for \( n \in \{0, 1, \ldots\} \)
distribution.history: The semicircle distribution was used by the physicist Eugene Wigner in the study of random matrices. The distribution was also used by Nikio Sato and John Tate in a conjecture in number theory

distribution.name: triangular distribution
triangle distribution
distribution.model: The triangular distribution arises from various simple combinations of continuous uniform distributions
distribution.parameter: \( w \in (0, \infty) \), scale, the width of the interval
\(c = a + p w\), the location of the vertex
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{2(x - a)}{(b - a)(c-a)} & a \le x \leq c, \\ \frac{2(b - x)}{(b - a)(b - c)} & c \lt x \le b \end{cases} \)
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{(x - a)^2}{(b - a)(c - a)} & a \le x \leq c, \\ 1 - \frac{(b - x)^2}{(b - a)(b - c)} & c \lt x \le b \end{cases}\)
distribution.qf: \(Q(u) = \begin{cases} a + \sqrt{(b - a)(c - a) u}, & \; u \in [0, (c - a) / (b - a)] \\ b - \sqrt{(1 - u)(b - a)(b - c)}, & u \in [(c - a) / (b - a), 1] \end{cases}\)
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = 2 \frac{(b - c) e^{a t} - (b - a) e^{c t} + (c - a) e^{b t}}{(b - a)(c - a)(b - c) t^2}, \; t \in (-\infty, \infty)\)
distribution.median: \(\begin{cases} a + \frac{\sqrt{(b - a)(c - a)}}{\sqrt{2}}, & c \ge \frac{a + b}{2}, \\ b - \frac{\sqrt{(b - a)(b - c)}}{\sqrt{2}}, & c \le \frac{a + b}{2} \end{cases}\)
distribution.q1: \(\begin{cases} a + \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}(b - a)(c - a)}, & c \geq \frac{3}{4} a + \frac{1}{4} b \\ b - \sqrt{\frac{3}{4}(b - a)(b - c)} & c \leq \frac{3}{4} a + \frac{1}{4} b \end{cases}\)
distribution.q3: \(\begin{cases} a + \sqrt{\frac{3}{4}(b - a)(c - a)}, & c \geq \frac{1}{4} a + \frac{3}{4} b \\ b - \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}(b - a)(b - c)}, & c \leq \frac{1}{4} a + \frac{3}{4} b \end{cases}\)

distribution.name: U-quadratic distribution
distribution.model: the U-quadratic distribution models certain symmetric, bimodal variables
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \frac{1}{2}\left[1 + \left(\frac{x - c}{w}\right)^3\right], \; x \in [a, b] \)

distribution.name: von Mises distribution
circular normal distribution
Tikhanov distribution
distribution.model: The von Mises distribution is used as an approximation to the wrapped normal distribution
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.entropy: \(-\beta \frac{I_1(\beta)}{I_0(\beta)} + \ln[2 \pi I_0(\beta)]\) where \(I_n\) is the modfied Bessel function of order \(n\)
distribution.history: The von Mises distribution is named for Richard von Mises based on his work in diffusion processes

distribution.name: Wald distribution
inverse Gaussian distribution
distribution.model: The Wald distribution governs the time that Brownian Motion with positive drift reaches a fixed positive value
distribution.cdf: \(\Phi\left(\sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{x}}\left(\frac{x}{\mu}-1\right)\right)\)\(+\exp\left(\frac{2\lambda}{\mu}\right)\Phi\left(-\sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{x}}\left(\frac{x}{\mu}+1\right)\right)\) where \(\Phi\left(\right)\) is the standard normal distribution function.
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The Wald distribution is named for Abraham Wald

distribution.name: Weibull distribution
distribution.model: The Weibull distribution is used to model the failure times
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = 1 - \exp\left[-\left(\frac{x}{\lambda}\right)^k\right], \; x \in (0, \infty)\)
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = \lambda \left[- \ln(1 - p)\right]^{1/k}, \; p \in (0, 1)\)
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{t^n \lambda^n}{n!} \Gamma\left(1 + \frac{n}{k}\right), \; t \in (-\infty, \infty), \; k \in (1, \infty)\) where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function
distribution.skew: \(\frac{\Gamma(1 + 3/k)\lambda^3 - 3\mu \sigma^2 - \mu^3}{\sigma^3}\) where \( \mu \) is the mean and \( \sigma \) is the standard deviation
distribution.history: The Weibull distribution is named for Waloddi Weibull who published a paper on the distribution in 1951. The distribution was used earlier by Maurice Frechet. The term Weibull distribution was first used in 1955 in a paper by Julius Lieblein

distribution.name: zeta distribution
Zipf distribution
distribution.model: The zeta distribution models ranks and sizes of certain randomly chosen items
distribution.pdf: \(f(k) = \frac{1}{\zeta(s) k^s}, \; k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) where \( \zeta \) is the zeta function
distribution.cdf: \(F(k) = \frac{H_{k,s}}{\zeta(s)}, \; k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), where \(H_{k,s}\) is a generalized harmonic number.
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in [0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.median: \( Q\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \) where \( Q \) is the quantile function
distribution.history: The Zipf distribution is named for the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf, who studied the distribution in the context of the frequency of words

distribution.name: location-scale distribution
distribution.model: Location scale distributions correspond to linear transformations (with positive slope) of a basic random variable, and often correspond to a change of units in a physical problem
distribution.parameter: the standard distribution, a continuous distribution with support on an interval \(S_0\)
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma} f_0\left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\right), \; x \in S\) where \(f_0\) is the probability density function of the standard distribution
distribution.mode: \(\mu + \sigma x_0\) where \(x_0\) is a mode of the standard distribution
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = F_0\left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\right), \; x \in S\) where \(F_0\) is the distribution function of the standard distribution
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = \mu + \sigma Q_0(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(Q_0\) is the quantile function of the standard distribution
distribution.mgf: \(M(t) = e^{\mu t} M_0(\sigma t)\) where \(M_0\) is the moment generating function of the standard distribution
distribution.cf: \(\varphi(t) = e^{i \mu t} \varphi_0(\sigma t)\) where \(\phi\) is the characteristic function of the standard distribution
distribution.moments: \(m(n) = \sum_{i=0}^n {n \choose i} \sigma^i \mu^{n-i} m_0(i), \; n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) where \(m_0(i)\) is the \(i\)th raw moment of the standard distribution
distribution.mean: \(\mu + \sigma \mu_0\) where \(\mu_0\) is the mean of the standard distribution
distribution.variance: \(\sigma^2 \sigma_0^2\) where \(\sigma_0^2\) is the variance of the standard distribution
distribution.skew: \(\gamma_{0,1}\) where \(\gamma_{0,1}\) is the skewness of the standard distribution
distribution.kurt: \(\gamma_{0,2}\) where \(\gamma_{0,2}\) is the kurtosis of the standard distribution
distribution.entropy: \(\ln(\sigma) + I_0\) where \(I_0\) is the entropy of the standard distribution
distribution.median: \(\mu + \sigma q_{0,2}\) where \(q_{0,2}\) is the median of the standard distribution
distribution.q1: \(\mu + \sigma q_{0,1}\) where \(q_{0,1}\) is the first quartile of the standard distribution
distribution.q3: \(\mu + \sigma q_{0,3}\) where \(q_{0,3}\) is the third quartile of the standard distribution

distribution.name: folded normal distribution
distribution.model: The folded normal distribution governs \(\left|X\right|\) when \(X\) has a normal distribution
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \Phi\left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\right) + \Phi\left(\frac{x + \mu}{\sigma}\right) - 1, \; x \in [0, \infty) \) where \( \Phi \) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.qf: \(F^{-1}(p), p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution funciton
distribution.mean: \(\sigma \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{\mu^2}{2 \sigma^2} \right) + \mu \left[1 - 2 \Phi\left(-\frac{\mu}{\sigma}\right) \right]\) where \(\Phi\) is the standard normal distribution function
distribution.variance: \( \mu^2 + \sigma^2 - \left\{ \sigma \sqrt{2/\pi} \exp(-\mu^2 / 2 \sigma^2) + \mu\left[1 - 2 \Phi(-\mu / \sigma)\right] \right\}^2 \) where \( \Phi \) is the standard normal distribution function

distribution.name: half normal distribution
distribution.model: The half normal distribution governs \(|X|\) when \(X\) has a normal disstribution with mean 0

distribution.name: birthday distribution
occupancy distribution
distribution.model: This distribution models the number of empty cells when \(n\) balls are distributed at random into \(m\) cells
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j = 0}^x f(j), \quad x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.skew: \(\frac{\mu_3 - 3 \mu_1 \mu_2 + 2 \mu_1^2}{\sigma^3}\) where \(\mu_i\) is the \(i\)th raw moment and \(\sigma\) is the standard deviation
distribution.kurt: \(\frac{\mu_4 - 4 \mu_1 \mu_3 + 6 \mu_1^2 -3 \mu_1^4}{\sigma^4} - 3\) where \(\mu_i\) is the \(i\)th raw moment and \(\sigma\) is the standard deviation
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \quad p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.entropy: \(H = -\sum_{x=0}^n \log[f(x)] f(x)\) where \(f\) is the probability density function

distribution.name: matching distribution
distribution.model: The matching distribution governs the number of matches in a random permutation of \(\{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\)
distribution.mode: \(0\) if \(n\) is even; \(1\) if \(n\) is odd
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j = 0}^x f(j), \; x \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.skew: \(\frac{\mu_3 - 3 \mu_1 \mu_2 + 2 \mu_1^2}{\sigma^3}\) where \(\mu_i\) is the \(i\)th raw moment and \(\sigma\) is the standard deviation
distribution.kurt: \(\frac{\mu_4 - 4 \mu_1 \mu_3 + 6 \mu_1^2 -3 \mu_1^4}{\sigma^4} - 3\) where \(\mu_i\) is the \(i\)th raw moment and \(\sigma\) is the standard deviation
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \quad p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.entropy: \(H = -\sum_{x=0}^n \log[f(x)] f(x)\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.history: The matching problem was first formulated by Pierre-Redmond Montmort

distribution.name: coupon-collector distribution
distribution.model: This distribution models the number number of samples needed to obtain \(k\) distinct values when sampling at random, with replacement from a population of \(m\) objects
distribution.parameter: \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), the number of distinct values to be obtained
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j = 0}^x f(j), \quad x \in \{k, k + 1, \ldots\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function

distribution.name: finite order statistic distribution
distribution.model: This distribution models an order statistic when a sample is chosen at random, without replacement, from a finite, ordered population

distribution.name: Erlang distribution
distribution.model: The Erlang probability distribution is related exponential and Gamma distributions and is used to examine the number of event arrivals. For instance telephone calls which might be made at the same time to the operators of the switching stations. This work on telephone traffic engineering has been expanded to consider waiting times in queueing systems in general
distribution.cdf: \(\scriptstyle\frac{\gamma(k,\,\lambda x)}{(k\,-\,1)!}\;=\;1\,-\,\sum_{n=0}^{k-1}\frac{1}{n!}e^{-\lambda x}(\lambda x)^{n}\)

distribution.name: Generalized Gamma distribution
distribution.model: The generalized gamma distribution is not often used to model life data by itself, but it is sometimes used to determine which of those life distributions should be used to model a particular set of data
distribution.pdf: \(f(x; \alpha, \beta, \delta) = \frac{(\delta/\alpha^\beta) x^{\beta-1} e^{-(x/\alpha)^\delta}}{\Gamma(\beta/\delta)}\), where \(\Gamma\) is the gamma function.
distribution.cdf: \(F(x; \alpha, \beta, \delta) = \frac{\gamma(\beta/\delta, (x/\alpha)^\delta)}{\Gamma(\beta/\delta)}\), where \(\gamma\) denotes lower incomplete gamma function

distribution.name: Makeham distribution
Gompertz-Makeham law of mortality
distribution.model: The Gompertz-Makeham law states that the death rate is the sum of an age-independent component and an age-dependent component, which increases exponentially with age
distribution.parameter: \(\kappa \in (0, \infty)\), all the parameters are in units reciprocal of the units of the variable, \(x\)
distribution.cdf: \(1-\exp(-\frac{\gamma x \log(\kappa) + \delta \kappa^x -\delta}{\log(\kappa)})\)

distribution.name: hypoexponential distribution
generalized Erlang distribution
distribution.model: The hypoexponential distribution has a coefficient of variation less than one, compared to the hyperexponential distribution, which has a coefficient of variation greater than one and the exponential distribution which has a coefficient of variation of one
distribution.cdf: Expressed as a phase-type distribution: \(1-\boldsymbol{\Lambda}e^{x\Theta}\boldsymbol{1}\), where \(\Theta=\Theta(\lambda_1,...,\lambda_n) \) is a phase-type matrix, and \( \alpha = (1,0,0,...,0)\)

distribution.name: doubly noncentral t distribution
distribution.model: The doubly noncentral t distribution is an extended version of the singly noncentral t distribution in that it has two noncentrality parameters instead of just one
distribution.history: See http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-842X.1969.tb00102.x/pdf

distribution.name: hyperexponential distribution
distribution.model: The hyperexponential distribution has a coefficient variation greater than one, compared to the hypoexponential distribution which has a coefficient variation less than one and the exponential distribution which has a coefficient variation of one

distribution.name: Muth distribution
distribution.model: The Muth distribution is related to reliability models. It has mostly a theoretical interest. Muth distribution has two basic properties: (i) the mode of this random model is a function involving the golden ratio and (ii) the second non-central moment can be expressed in terms of the exponential integral function. The moments of higher order cannot be expressed in a simple way. The Muth distribution does not have the variate generation property for simulation purposes. Its quantile function can be expressed in closed form in terms of the negative branch of the Lambert W function. The limit distributions of the maxima and minima of the Muth distribution are the Gumbel and Weibull distributions, respectively

distribution.name: generalized error distribution
generalized normal distribution
generalized Gaussian distribution
exponential power distribution
distribution.model: The error distribution is a parametric family of symmetric distributions. It adds a shape parameter to the normal distribution

distribution.name: minimax distribution
distribution.model: The Minimax distribution is an alternative two-parameter distribution of the Beta distribution

distribution.name: noncentral F distribution
distribution.model: The noncentral F distribution is a generalization of the ordinary F distribution

distribution.name: increasing-decreasing-bathtub distribution
distribution.model: The IDB distribution can be used to model either an increasing, decreasing or bathtub shaped failure rate function, which is a combination of a linearly increasing failure rate and a decreasing failure rate function

distribution.name: Benford's law
first digit law
significant digit law
distribution.model: Benford's law states that in lists of numbers from many (but not all) real-life sources of data, the leading digit is distributed in a specific, non-uniform way

distribution.name: doubly noncentral F distribution
distribution.model: The doubly noncentral F distribution is an extended version of the singly noncentral F distribution in that it has two noncentrality parameters instead of just one. In other words, the doubly noncentral F-distribution describes the distribution \(\frac{X/n_1}{Y/n_2}\) for two independently distributed noncentral chi-squared variables \(X \sim chi_{n_1}^2(\lambda_1)\) and \(Y \sim chi_{n_2}^2(\lambda_2)\)
distribution.pdf: \(f(x)= \sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}[\frac{e^{-\delta/2}(\frac{1}{2}\delta)^j}{j!}][\frac{e^{-\gamma/2}(\frac{1}{2}\gamma)^k}{k!}]\times n_1^{(n_1/2)+j}n_2^{(n_2/2)+k}x^{(n_1/2)+j-1}\times (n_2+n_1 x)^{-\frac{1}{2}(n_1+n_2)-j-k}\times [B(\frac{1}{2}n_1+j,\frac{1}{2}n_2+k)]^{-1}\), w where \(n_1\) and \(n_2\) are the degrees of freedom of the numerator and denominator, and \(B\) is the beta function

distribution.name: two-sided power distribution
distribution.model: The two-sided power distribution is an alternative to the triangular distribution, allowing for a nonlinear distribution. Triangular and uniform distributions are special cases of the two-sided power distribution
distribution.pdf: \(f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{n}{b-a}(\frac{x-a}{m-a})^{n-1}, a\lt x\le m \\ \frac{n}{b-a}(\frac{b-x}{b-m})^{n-1}, m\le x\lt b \end{cases}\)

distribution.name: extreme value distribution
Gumbel distribution
distribution.model: The Extreme Value distribution is the limiting distribution of the minimum of a large number of unbounded identically distributed random variables
distribution.cdf: \( F(x) = \exp\left[-\exp\left(-\frac{x - a}{b}\right)\right], \; x \in (-\infty, \infty) \)
distribution.mgf: \( M(t) = e^{a t} \Gamma(1 - b t), \; t \in (-\infty, 1/b) \) where \( \Gamma \) is the gamma function
distribution.mean: \( a + b \gamma \) where \( \gamma \) is Euler's constant
distribution.skew: \( 12 \sqrt{6} \zeta(3) / \pi^3 \), where \(\zeta\) is the Riemann zeta function
distribution.history: The Gumbel distribution is named for Emil Gumbel, who derived it in his study of extreme values in 1954

distribution.name: Lomax distribution
Pareto Type II distribution
distribution.model: The Lomax distribution is essentially a Pareto distribution that has been shifted so that its support begins at zero
distribution.cdf: \(1- \left[{1+ {x \over \lambda}}\right]^{-\alpha}\)

distribution.name: generalized Pareto distribution
distribution.model: The generalized Pareto distribution allows a continuous range of possible shapes that includes both the exponential and Pareto distributions as special cases

distribution.name: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
Kolmogorov distribution
distribution.model: The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test can be modified to serve as a goodness of fit test

distribution.name: student t non-central distribution
inverted gamma distribution
inverse gamma distribution
distribution.cdf: \(\frac{\Gamma(\alpha,\beta/x)}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \!\)

distribution.name: Gompertz distribution
distribution.cdf: \(1-\exp\left(-\eta\left(e^{bx}-1 \right)\right)\)
distribution.mgf: \(\text{E}\left(e^{-t x}\right)=\eta e^{\eta}\text{E}_{t/b}\left(\eta\right)\), \(\text{with E}_{t/b}\left(\eta\right)=\int_1^\infty e^{-\eta v} v^{-t/b}dv,\ t>0\)

distribution.name: multinomial distribution
distribution.pdf: \( f(x_1, x_2, \cdots, x_k)={n\choose x_1,x_2,\cdots, x_k}p_1^{x_1}p_2^{x_2}\cdots p_k^{x_k} \)
distribution.variance: \(\textstyle{\mathrm{Var}}(X_i) = n p_i (1-p_i)\), where \(\textstyle {\mathrm{Cov}}(X_i,X_j) = - n p_i p_j~~(i\neq j)\)

distribution.name: negative hypergeometric distribution
distribution.model: If \({x \choose 2} \lt\lt W\) and \({b \choose 2} \lt\lt B\) then \(X\) can be approximated as a negative binomial random variable with parameters \(r = b\) and \(p = \frac{W}{W+B}\). This approximation simplifies the distribution by looking as a system with replacement for large values of \(W\) and \(B\)

distribution.name: gamma-Poisson distribution
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j=k}^x f(j) , \; x \in \{k, k+1, \ldots\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The alternative name Pascal distribution is in honor of Blaise Pascal who used the distribution in his solution to the Problem of Points

distribution.name: Polya distribution
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j=k}^x f(j) , \; x \in \{k, k+1, \ldots\}\) where \(f\) is the probability density function
distribution.qf: \(Q(p) = F^{-1}(p), \; p \in (0, 1)\) where \(F\) is the distribution function
distribution.history: The alternative name Pascal distribution is in honor of Blaise Pascal who used the distribution in his solution to the Problem of Points

distribution.name: noncentral beta distribution
distribution.cdf: \(F(x) = \sum_{j=0}^\infty \frac{1}{j!}\left(\frac{\lambda}{2}\right)^je^{-\lambda/2}B(x; a+j,b)\) where \(B\) is regularized incomplete beta function

relation.statement: If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) is a sequence of independent Bernoulli variables, each with parameter \(p \in [0, 1]\) then \(Y = \sum_{i = 1}^n X_i\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n\) and \(p\).

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots)\) is a sequence of independent Bernoulli variables, each with parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\), then \(Y = \min\{n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}: X_n = 1\}\) has the geometric distribution with parameter \(p\).

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots)\) is a sequence of independent Bernoulli variables, each with parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\), then for \(ki \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), \(Y = \min\{n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}: \sum_{i=1}^n X_i = k\}\) has the negative binomial distribution with parmeters \(k\) and \(p\).
If \(X\) has the Bernoulli distribution with parameter \(\frac{1}{2}\) then \(2 X - 1\) has the Rademacher distribution.
The beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha = \frac{1}{2}\) and \(\beta = \frac{1}{2}\) is the arcsine distribution.

The beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha = 1\) and \(\beta = 1\) is the (standard) continuous uniform distribution. Also, the k-th order statistic from sample of n independent continuous uniform variables is Beta(k,n+1-k).

If \(X\) has the beta general distribution with parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\), \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) and \(L \lt R\), then \(Y = \frac{X-L}{R-L}\) has beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

If \(X\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = \frac{X}{1 - X}\) has the inverse beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

If \(X\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha = \frac{3}{2}\) and \(\beta = \frac{3}{2}\), and \(r \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = r (2 X - 1)\) has the semicircle distribution with parameter \(r\).
If \(X\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) then \(Y = 1 - X\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\beta\) and \(\alpha\).

If \(X\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta = 1\), and \(r \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = X^r\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\frac{\alpha}{r}\) and \(1\).
If \(X\) has the beta distribution with left parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and right parameter \(1\), then \(Y = \frac{1}{X}\) has the Pareto distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha\).

If \(P\) has the beta distribution with parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) and if the conditional distribution of \(X\) given \(P = p\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(p\), then \(X\) has the beta-binomial distribution with parameters \(n\), \(\alpha\), and \(\beta\).
The standard uniform distribution is a special case of beta-binomial distribution with \( \a=\b=1 \)
The negative hypergeometric distribution is a special case of beta-binomial distribution with \( n=n_1, a=n_2, b=n_3 \)

If \(X_n\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and fixed \(p \in (0, 1)\) then then the distribution of \(Z_n = \frac{X_n - n p}{\sqrt{n p (1 - p)}}\) converges to the standard normal distribution as \(n \to \infty\).

The binomial distribution with parameters \(n = 1\) and \(p \in [0, 1]\) is the Bernoulli distribution with parameter \(p\). Also, if \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) is a sequence of independent Bernoulli variables, each with parameter \(p \in [0, 1]\) then \(Y = \sum_{i = 1}^n X_i\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n\) and \(p\).

If \(X\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(p \in [0, 1]\); \(Y\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(p\); and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(m + n\) and \(p\).

Suppose that \(\boldsymbol{X} = (X_1, X_2, \ldots)\) is a Bernoulli trials sequence with parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\). For \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) let \(Y_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\), so that \(Y_n\) has the binomial distribution with parameters \(n\) and \(p\). If \(m \lt n\) then the distribution of \(Y_m\) given \(Y_n = k\) is hypergeoemtric with parameters \(m\), \(n\), and \(k\).

The binomial distribution with parameters \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(p \in (0, 1)\) converges to the Poisson distribution with parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) if \(n \to \infty\), \(p \to 0\), with \(n p \to \lambda\).

For \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), let \(Y_n\) denote the number of successes in the first \(n\) of a sequence of Bernoulli trials, so that \(Y_n\) has the binomial distribution with trial parameter \(n\) and sucess parameter \(p\). Then for \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), \(Z_k = \min\{n: Y_n \geq k\} - k\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(k\) and success parameter \(p\).

If \(X\) has the Cauchy distribution with location parameter \(\alpha_1 \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and location parameter \(\beta_1 \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the Cauchy distribution with location parameter \(\alpha_2 \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\beta_2 \in (0, \infty)\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the Cauchy distribution with location parameter \(\alpha_1 + \alpha_2\) and scale parameter \(\beta_1 + \beta_2\).
If \(Z_1\) and \(Z_2\) are two independent standard normal variables, then the ratio \(\frac{Z_1}{Z_2}\) has the standard Cauchy distribution.
If \(Z_1\) and \(Z_2\) are two independent normally distributed random variables \(\sim N(0, \sigma^2)\), then the ratio \(\frac{Z_1}{Z_2}\) has the standard Cauchy distribution.

If \(X\) has Cauchy distribution with location parameter \(\alpha \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\), \(a \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(a + b X\) has the Cauchy distribution with location parameter \(a + b \alpha\) and location parameter \(\beta b\).

If \(X\) has the chi-square distribution with \(m \in (0, \infty)\) degrees of freedom; \(Y\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n \in (0, \infty)\) degrees of freedom; and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the chi-square distribution with \(m + n\) degrees of freedom.

If \(X\) has a chi-square distribution with \(\nu \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom, and \(c \in (0, \infty)\) , then \(Y = c X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(k = \frac{\nu}{2}\) and scale parameter \(\theta = 2 c\).

If \(X_n\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom, then the distribution of \(Z = \frac{X_n - n}{\sqrt{2 n}}\) converges to the standard normal distribution as \(n \to \infty\).

If \(U\) has the chi-square distribution with \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom; \(V\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom; and \(U\) and \(V\) are independent, then \(X = \frac{U/m}{V/n}\) hs the \(F\)-distribution with \(m\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(n\) degrees of freedom in the denominator

If \(X\) has the non-central chi-square distribution with \(\nu \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom and non-centrality parameter \(\lambda = 0\), then \(X\) has a chi-square distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom.
If \(X\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom, then \(\sqrt{X}\) has the chi distribution with \(n\) degrees of freedom.

If \(Z\) has the standard normal distribution, \(V\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n \in (0, \infty)\) degrees of freedom, and \(Z\) and \(V\) are independent, then \(T = \frac{Z}{\sqrt{V / n}}\) has the students's \(t\)-distribution with \(n\) degrees of freedom.

If \(X\) has the Poisson distribution with parameter \( rac{
u^2}{2 \sigma^2}\) where \(
u \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), and the conditional distribution of \(Y\) given \(X = x \in \{0, 1, 2, \ldots\}\) is chi-square with \(2 x + 2\) degrees of freedom, then \(\sigma \sqrt{X}\) has the Rice distribution with distance parameter \(
u\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) is uniformly distributed on the interval \([a, b]\) and \(c, d \in (-\infty, \infty)\) with \(c \ne 0\), then \(Y = cX + d\) is uniformly distributed on \([ca + d, cb + d]\) if \(c \gt 0\) or on \([cb + d, ca + d]\) if \(c \lt 0\)
The continuous uniform distribution on \([0, 1]\) is the standard uniform distribution

If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent and each is uniformly distributed on the interval \([a, b]\), then \(X + Y\) has the triangular distribution with parameters \(a\), \(b\), and \(c = \frac{a+b}{2}\).
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\), then \(-\beta \ln(1 - X)\) has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\beta\).

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\), and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{\mu}{(1 - X)^{1/\beta}}\) has the Pareto distribution with location parameter \(\mu\) and shape parameter \(\beta\).
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution and \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) then \(X^{1/\alpha}\) has the beta distribution with left parameter \(\alpha\) and right parameter 1.
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution then \(\tan[\pi(X - \frac{1}{2})]\) has the standard Cauchy distribution.
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution then \(\sin^2(\frac{\pi}{2} X)\) has the arcsine distribution.

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(b \in (0, \infty)\), and \(p \in (0, 1)\) then \(\frac{1}{b}\ln\left(\frac{1 - p}{1 - p^{1 - X}}\right)\) has the exponential-logarithmic distribution with parameters \(b\) and \(p\).
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution and \(p \in (0, 1)\) then \(\lceil \frac{\ln(1 - X)}{\ln(1 - p)}\rceil\) has the geometric distribution with parameter \(p\).

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\), and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\mu - \sigma \ln(-\ln(X))\) has the Gumbel distribution with location prarameter \(\mu\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution then \(\frac{2}{\pi} \ln[\tan(\frac{\pi}{2} X)]\) has the hyperbolic secant distribution.

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\), \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\mu + b \ln(2 \min\{X, 1 - X\})\) has the Laplace distribution with location parameter \(\mu\) and scale parameter \(b\).

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\), and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\mu + \sigma \ln\left(\frac{X}{1 - X}\right)\) has the logistic distribution with location parameter \(\mu\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\), and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\alpha \left(\frac{X}{1 - X}\right)^{1/\beta}\) has the log-logistic distribution with scale parameter \(\alpha\) and shape parameter \(\beta\).
If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\sigma \sqrt{-2 \ln(1 - X)}\) has the Rayleigh distribution with scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the standard uniform distribution, \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\sigma (-\ln(1 - X))^{1/\alpha}\) has the Weibull distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) is a sequence of independent random variables, each with the standard uniform distribution, then \(sum_{i=1}^n X_i\) has the Irwin-Hall distribution with parameter \(n\).

If \(X\) has the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(r \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(s \in (0, \infty)\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(\min\{X, Y\}\) has the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(r + s\).
If \(X\) has the exponential distribution with parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) then \(Y = e^{-\lambda X}\) has the standard uniform distribution.

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) is a sequence of independent random variables, each with the exponential distribution with parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) then \(Y = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(n\) and scale parameter \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\). Also, If \(X\) has the gamma distributed with parameter shape parameter \(k = 1\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) then and then \(X\) has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\lambda\) (and hence rate parameter \(1/\lambda\).

If \(a \in (0, \infty)\) and \(X\) has the exponential distribution with parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) then \(Y = a e^X\) has the Pareto distribution with scale parameter \(a\) and shape parameter \(\lambda\).

If \(X\) has the standard exponential distribution, \(k \in (0, \infty)\), and \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = b X^{1/k}\) has the Weibull distribution with shape parameter \(k\) and scale parameter \(b\).

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots)\) is a sequence of indpendent random variables, each with the standard exponential distribution, then the distribution of \(\max\{X_1, \ldots, X_n\} - \ln(n)\) converges to the standard Gumbel distribution.

If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent random variables and each has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(X - Y\) has the Laplace distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the Rademacher distribution, and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X V\) has the Laplace distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the standard exponential distribution, \(Z\) has the standard normal distribution, \(X\) and \(Z\) are independent, \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\), and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\mu + \sigma Z \sqrt{2 X}\) has the Laplace distribution with location parameter \(\mu\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the F-distribution with \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom in the denominator, then \(\frac{1}{X}\) has the F-distribution with \(n\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(m\) degrees of freedom in the denominator.

If \(X\) has the F-distribution with \(m \in (0, \infty)\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(n \in (0, \infty)\) degrees of freedom in the denominator, then \(\frac{(m/n)X}{1 + (m/n)X}\) has the beta distribution with left parameter \(\frac{m}{2}\) and right parameter \(\frac{n}{2}\).

If \(X\) has the chi-square distribution with \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) degrees of freedom in the denominator, then the distribution of \(m X\) converges to the chi-square distribution with \(m\) degrees of freedom as \(n \to \infty\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) and \(c \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = cX\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha\) and scale parameter \(c \lambda\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha + \beta\) and scale parameter \(\lambda\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distributed with parameter shape parameter \(k = 1\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\) then and then \(X\) has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\lambda\) (and hence rate parameter \(1/\lambda\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(k \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\frac{2 X}{\lambda}\) has the chi-square distribution with \(k\) degrees of freedom.

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and scale parameter \(c \in (0, \infty)\), then \(X\) has the Erlang distribution with shape parameter \(k\) and scale parameter \(c\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(k = \frac{3}{2}\) and scale parameter \(\theta = 2 a^2\) where \(a \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\sqrt{X}\) has the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution with parameter \(a\).

If \(X_k\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(k \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(b \in (0, \infty)\) then the distribution of \(\frac{X - k b}{\sqrt{k} b}\) converges to the standard normal distribution as \(k \to \infty\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(\frac{X}{X + Y}\) has the beta distribution with left parameter \(\alpha\) and right parameter \(\beta\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\lambda\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(\frac{X}{Y}\) has the inverted beta distribution with shape parameters \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

If \(X\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\frac{1}{x}\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{1}{X}\) has the Levy distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\frac{2}{\sigma}\).
If \(X\) has the geometric distributin on \(\{0, 1, \ldots\}\) then \(X + 1\) has the geometric distribution on \(\{1, 2 \ldots\}\).

If \(X\) has the geometric distribution on \(\{1, 2, \ldots\}\) with parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\) and \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), then the conditional distribution of \(X\) given \(X \in \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\) converges to the uniform distribution on \(\{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\) as \(p \to 0\).

If \(X_n\) has the geometric distribution on \(\{1, 2, \ldots\}\) with parmeter \(p_n \in (0, 1)\) for each \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(n p_n \to r \in (0, \infty)\) as \(n \to \infty\), then the distribution of \(\frac{X_n}{n}\) converges to the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(r\).

If \(X\) has the Gumbel distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), and \(a \in (-\infty, \infty)\), \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(a + b X\) has the Gumbel distribution with location parameter \(a + b \mu\) and scale parameter \(b \sigma\).

If \(X\) has the Gumbel distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\exp\left[-\exp\left(\frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}\right)\right]\) has the standard uniform distribution.

If \(X\) has the hypergeometric distribution with population size \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), sample size \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}\) and type parameter \(r \in \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}\) then \(n - X\) has the hypergeometric distribution with population size \(m\), sample size \(n\), and type parameter \(m - r\).

Let \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) and \(r_m \in \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}\) for each \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\) with \(\frac{r_m}{m} \to p \in (0, 1)\) as \(m \to \infty\). The hypergeometric distribution with population size \(m\), sample size \(n\), and type parameter \(r_m\) converges to the binomial distribution with trial parameter \(n\) and success parameter \(p\) as \(m \to \infty\).

If \(X\) has the hypergeometric distribution with population size \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), sample size \(n = 1\), and type parameter \(r \in \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}\), then \(X\) has the Bernoulli distribution with parameter \(\frac{r}{m}\).
If \(X\) has the hyperbolic secant distribution then \(\frac{2}{\pi} \arctan[\exp(\frac{\pi}{2} X)]\) has the standard uniform distribution.

If \(X\) has the Irwin-Hall distribution with parameter \(m \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), \(Y\) has the Irwin-Hall distribution with parameter \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the Irwin-Hall distribution with parameter \(m + n\).
The Irwin-Hall distribution with parameter \(1\) is the standard uniform distribution.
The Irwin-Hall distribution with parmeter \(2\) is the triangular distribution with left endpoint \(0\), right endpoint \(1\) and midpoint \(\frac{1}{2}\).

If \(X\) has the inverted beta distribution with shape parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{1}{X}\) has the inverted beta distribution with shape parameters \(\beta\) and \(\alpha\).

If \(X\) has the inverted beta distribution with shape parameters \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\) and \(\beta \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{\beta}{\alpha} X\) has the F-distribution with \(2 \alpha\) degrees of freedom in the numerator and \(2 \beta\) degrees of freedom in the denominator.
If \(X\) has the Laplace distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(|X|\) has the exponential distribution with scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the Levy distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{X - \mu}}\) has the folded normal distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\frac{1}{\sigma}\).

If \(X\) has the Levy distribution with location parameter \(0\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\frac{1}{X}\) has the gamma distribution with shape parameter \(\frac{1}{x}\) and scale parameter \(\frac{2}{\sigma}\).

If \((X_1, X_2, \ldots)\) is a sequence of independent random variables, each with the logarithmic distribution with parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\) and \(N\) has the Poisson distribution with parameter \(\lambda \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\sum_{i=1}^N X_i\) has the negative binomial distribution with parameters \(\lambda\) and \(p\).

relations.relation: %logistic to standard uniform logistic distribution continuous uniform distribution If \(X\) has the logistic distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{1}{1 + \exp\left(\frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}\right)}\) has the standard uniform distribution. nonlinear transformation doi:10.1080/07408170590948512 doi:10.1198/000313008X270448

relation.statement: If \(X\) has the skew-logistic distribution with parameter \(\alpha \in (0, \infty)\), then \(Y = \ln(1+e^{-X})\) has the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(\alpha\).

If \(X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), \(Y\) has the log-normal distribuiton with location parameter \(\nu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\tau \in (0, \infty)\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X Y\) has the log-normal distirbution with location parameter \(\mu + \tau\) and scale parameter \(\sqrt{\sigma^2 + \tau^2}\).

If \(X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parmaeter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), and \(a \neq 0\) then \(a X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(a \mu\) and scale parameter \(|a| \sigma\).

If \(X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\), and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(a X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(\ln(a) + \mu\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the log-normal distribution with location parameter \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\ln(X)\) has the normald distribution with location parameter \(\mu\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).
If \(X\) has the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution with scale parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\) and \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(b X\) has the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution with scale parameter \(a b\).
If \(X\) has the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution with scale parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\frac{X}{a}\) has the chi distribution with 3 degrees of freedom.

If \(X\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(r \in (0, \infty)\) and success parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\), \(Y\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(s \in (0, \infty)\) and success parameter \(p\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(X + Y\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(r + s\) and success parameter \(p\).

The negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(1\) and success parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\) is the geometric distribution with success parameter \(p\). Also, if \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) is a sequence of independent Geometric(p) random variables, their sum \(\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i} is negative binomial(n,p).

If \(p_r \in (0, 1)\) for each \(r \in (0, \infty)\) and \(r \frac{p}{1-p} \to \lambda \in (0, \infty)\) as \(r \to \infty\), then the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(r\) and success parameter \(p_r\) converges to the Poisson distribution with parameter \(\lambda\).
relation.type: limiting distribution with respect to parameter

relation.statement: If for every t > 0 the number of arrivals in the time interval [0,t] follows the Poisson distribution with mean \(\lambda t\), then the sequence of inter-arrival times are independent and identically distributed exponential random variables with mean \(\fract{1}{Î»}\).

If \(X\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(r \in (0, \infty)\) and success parameter \(p \in (0, \infty)\), then the distribution of \(\frac{p X - r (1 - p)}{\sqrt{r (1 - p}}\) converges to the standard normal distribution at \(r \to \infty\).

For \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), let \(Z_k\) denote the number of failures before the \(k\)th success in a sequence of Bernoulli trials with success parameter \(p \in (0, 1)\), so that \(Z_k\) has the negative binomial distribution with stopping parameter \(k\) and success parameter \(p\). Then for \(n \in \{1, 2, \ldots\}\), \(Y_n = \max\{k: k + Z_k \leq n\}\) has the binomial distribution with trial parameter \(n\) and success parameter \(p\).
If \(X\) has a normal distribution with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and variance \(\sigma^2\), then \(Y = e^X\) has the log-normal distribution with parameters \(\mu\) and \(\sigma^2\).

If \(X\) is has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(|X|\) has the folded normal distribution with parameters \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\).
If \(X\) is has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) = 0 and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(|X|\) has a half-normal distribution with parameter \(\sigma\).

If \(X\) has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then variable \(Y = \frac{X^2}{\sigma^2}\) has a non-central chi-square distribution with one degree of freedom and non-centrality parameter \(\frac{\mu^2}{\sigma^2}\).

If \(X\) is has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), and if \(a, b \in [-\infty, \infty]\) with \(a \lt b\), then the conditional distribution of \(X\) given \(X \in (a,b)\) is the truncated normal distribution with location parameter \(\mu\), scale parameter \(\sigma\), minimum value \(a\), and maximum value \(b\).

If \(X\) has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\frac{1}{(X - \mu)^2}\) has the Levy distribution with location parameter 0 and scale parameter \(\frac{1}{\sigma^2}\).

Let \(
u \in [0, \infty)\), \(	heta \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\). If \(X\) has the normal distribution with mean \(
u \cos(	heta)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma\), \(Y\) has the normal distribution with mean \(
u \sin(	heta)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma\), and \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, then \(\sqrt{X^2 + Y^2}\) has the Rice distribution with distance parameter \(
u\) and scale parameter \(\sigma\).
If \(X\) has the normal distribution with mean \(\mu = 0\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 1\), then \(X\) has a standard normal distribution.
If \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) are independent standard normal random variables, then \(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2\) has the chi-square distribution with \(n\) degrees of freedom.

If \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) are independent normally distributed random variables with mean \(\mu \in (-\infty, \infty)\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \in (0, \infty)\), then \(T = \frac{\overline{X} - \mu}{S / \sqrt{n}}\) has the students t distribution with \(n-1\) degrees of freedom.

If \(X_1\), \(X_2\), and \(X_3\) are independent random variables, each with the normal distribuiton with mean \(0\) and standard deviation \(a \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\sqrt{X_1^2 + X_2^2 + X_3^2}\) has the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution with parameter \(a\).
If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent variables, each with the standard normal distribution, then \(\frac{X}{Y}\) has the standard Cauchy distribution.

If \(X\) has the Pareto distribution with shape parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(b \in (0, \infty)\), then \(\ln\left(\frac{X}{b}\right)\) has the exponential distribution with rate parameter \(a\).

If \(X\) has the Pareto distribution with shape parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(b \in (0, \infty)\), and \(c \in (0, \infty)\) then \(c X\) has the Pareto distribution with shape parameter \(a\) and scale parameter \(b c\).

If \(X\) has the Pareto distribution with shape parameter \(a \in (0, \infty)\) and scale parameter \(b \in (0, \infty)\) then \(\frac{b}{X}\) has the beta distribution with left shape parameter \(a\) and right shape parameter \(1\).
